Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ARI-LA: Low-Dose Inspection for Nuclear Threats Using Monochromatic Gamma-Rays

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Low-dose inspection for nuclear threats using monochromatic gamma-rays is a novel method to detect shielded nuclear material (SNM) with a potential to significantly outperform currently employed methods. The key advantage of the method we are pursuing is in low dose (<20 mrad), ability for high-speed screening, accuracy in identification of nuclear materials, and relatively low cost and simplicity in design and operation. The advantages are achievable through use of ultra-compact superconducting accelerator technology applied to sources development, which can be tailored to produce multiple monoenergetic gamma rays and/or neutrons. Furthermore, monoenergetic sources coupled with the development of advanced radiation detectors and a new information science-driven approach for system design and data analysis have a potential to create unprecedented performance of the system in view of safety, efficiency and accuracy.

The unique and innovative approach to the design is the enabling factor for future SNM detection technologies. Integration of the novel method of monoenergetic source generation through use of a new generation of ultra-compact accelerators with advanced imaging detectors has a potential for a paradigm shift in the ability to rapidly and accurately clear objects from nuclear threats. Moreover, this interdisciplinary work requires a broad combined expertize in the areas of compact hadron accelerators, monochromatic gamma-ray sources, detectors, and algorithms making our team particularly well-suited for the task. This research combines several new and high-risk ideas and, if successful, could bring about revolutionary advances in the methods to detect shielded SNM, with broad impacts and benefits to the welfare and security of the nation and society and promote the diversity and public understanding of science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Current research on detection of shielded special nuclear materials suggests that active interrogation methods utilizing external source of radiation to image cargo or to excite nuclear materials suffer from large radiation doses inflicted upon the cargo and detectors. As part of the research, we investigated the applicability of low-energy nuclear reactions (LENR) as an alternative to currently employed x-ray based methods. LENR are capable of producing monoenergetic photons and neutrons that can be used for imaging of the contents of large cargo and to point to nuclear materials by inducing characteristic signatures. In particular, our main research goal was to develop a Cherenkov-based imaging detector array for use in active interrogation techniques involving monoenergetic photons as the means of low-dose imaging. Cherenkov detectors are different from traditionally used scintillators: they are based on refractive index of the material (thus, water or transparent plastic/glass can be used), making detectors non-hazardous in operation and widely available for large coverage applications. Because of this dependence on refractive index, gamma rays have to possess certain energy in order to induce a signal in our detectors, called energy threshold. This effectively reduces the low-energy background making our detectors particularly suitable for active interrogation applications and ensuring no damage to the detectors in high-radiation environments. In addition to potential detector damage in active interrogation applications, traditional detectors tend to suffer from dead-time (responsible for loss of information in high-rate environment) and pulse pileup (happens when radiation pulses arrive too close to each other to be resolved, which depends on timing of the detector).  One of the drawbacks of Cherenkov detectors is low energy spectroscopy, which reduces the information that can be extracted from the signal analysis.

 

To achieve out goals, we designed a Cherenkov detector using widely available material, quartz, to be highly efficient at detecting gamma rays in high radiation situations without detector deadtime or pulse pileup by taking advantage of the inherent energy threshold and virtually instantaneous light emission properties.  This detector is immune to neutrons, so it can be used in mixed neutron-gamma fields without interference. Our detector was designed and optimized for light collection leading to spectroscopic capabilities from the Cherenkov radiation. We constructed a prototype array of eight Cherenkov detectors that was used to produce images of various materials.  These experiments produced two types of images: the first is a simple 2-D planar image of the total transmission through the objects used to provide relative density of the contents, and the second involves the same data but is analyzed using our spectroscopic algorithms producing a spatial map (image) of the calculated effective atomic number of the material, indicating whether heavy materials (lead or uranium) are present in the cargo.

 

One of the main outcomes of this project is demonstration of material imaging using Cherenkov detectors. This has a potential broad impact on high-energy physics applications as well any conditions featuring high intensity radiation flux (for example reactor core instrumentation). This project has also had a significant impact on human development, including three graduate students involved, two undergraduate student research assistants and senior design class projects offered yearly since the beginning of the project.
